benchmark_details.name: DARKBENCH
benchmark_details.overview: We introduce DarkBench, a comprehensive benchmark for detecting dark design patterns—manipulative techniques that influence user behavior—in interactions with large language models (LLMs). Our benchmark comprises 660 prompts across six categories: brand bias, user retention, sycophancy, anthropomorphism, harmful generation, and sneaking.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To empirically measure the presence of dark patterns in LLMs and provide a standardized framework for evaluation.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dark patterns in DarkBench are derived primarily from an analysis of the incentives arising from the chatbot subscription-based business model. We do not claim full coverage of all the motivations facing an LLM developer.

data.source: Generated prompts specific to the six categories of dark patterns.
data.annotation: Annotated using a combination of human annotators and LLM models.

methodology.calculation: Results are calculated based on the incidence of dark patterns in the responses of the evaluated models to the prompts.
methodology.interpretation: Responses indicating the presence of defined dark patterns are evaluated against the benchmark for accuracy.
methodology.baseline_results: Average occurrence of dark pattern instances varies across models, with specific detection rates outlined for each of the six categories.
methodology.validation: Evaluated against a set of 14 models with results cross-validated by multiple annotators.
